content.question: A particle moves along a line so that its position at any time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math> is given by <math alttext="s of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>s</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. If <math alttext="s double prime of t equals, 2 minus the square root of t cubed plus 1, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>s</mi><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><msqrt><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></math> and <math alttext="s prime of 1 equals 1.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></math>, then the velocity of the particle at <math alttext="t equals 2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></math> is

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts
